byline.original: By CORNELIA DEAN and RACHEL NUWER

abstract: Researchers in British Columbia say lethal and highly contagious marine virus has been detected for first time in wild salmon in Pacific Northwest, stirring concern that it could spread there as it has elsewhere; virus does not affect people but is scourge of fish farms.
snippet: The contagion, which does not affect people but is a scourge of fish farms, was reported by researchers in British Columbia, stirring concern that it could spread there, as it has elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The contagion, which does not affect people but is a scourge of fish farms, was reported by researchers in British Columbia, stirring concern that it could spread there, as it has elsewhere.

headline.main: Salmon-Killing Virus Seen for First Time in the Wild on the Pacific Coast
headline.print_headline: Salmon-Killing Virus Seen for First Time in the Wild on the Pacific Coast
headline.seo: Infectious Salmon Anemia Reported in Wild Pacific Fish
